EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper level high pressure prevailed on August 6, 2018. High temperatures and humidity combined to create dangerous heat indices across parts of eastern Arkansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values exceeded 105 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure expanded east from the Oklahoma/Texas Panhandle region into the middle Red River Valley of Southeast Oklahoma, Southwest Arkansas, Northeast Texas, and North Louisiana during June 29th. Very dry conditions due to the developing drought conditions across North Louisiana combined with the compressional warming beneath the ridge resulted in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid 90s to near 100 degrees. Limited mixing was also observed, with resultant heat indices ranging between 105 and 110 degrees.

Very dry conditions due to the developing drought conditions across North Louisiana combined with the compressional warming beneath the ridge resulted in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid 90s to near 100 degrees. Limited mixing was also observed, with resultant heat indices ranging between 105 and 110 degrees.

High pressure aloft brought dry conditions and extreme temperatures to the Coachella Valley and San Diego County Deserts. Temperatures reached 112 in Palm Springs and 113 in Ocotillo Wells on June 13.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The San Diego County Deserts experienced extreme high temperatures on June 12 and 13 as high pressure aloft brought dry and hot temperatures to the region. Ocotillo Wells recorded a temperature of 109 on the 12th and 113 on the 13th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure aloft brought dry conditions and extreme temperatures to the Coachella Valley and San Diego County Deserts. Temperatures reached 112 in Palm Springs and 113 in Ocotillo Wells on June 13.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Coachella Valley experienced extreme high temperatures due to a high pressure aloft bringing dry and warm conditions to the region. Palm Springs recorded a temperature of 112 on June 13 and 14. Overnight lows were in the mid-80s in the Coachella Valley.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A heatwave impacted the Coachella Valley and San Diego County deserts on June 21-22 due to high pressure aloft bringing in dry and hot conditions to those areas. Temperatures in the Coachella Valley reached between 114 and 116 and temperatures in the San Diego County Deserts reached 114-115 on June 22. One person died in Ocotillo Wells Recreational State Park due to heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extreme temperatures were recorded in the Coachella Valley on June 21 and 22 as high pressure aloft brought dry and hot temperatures into the region. On June 22, Palm Springs recorded a high temperature of 116 and Thermal recorded a high temperature of 114.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A heatwave impacted the Coachella Valley and San Diego County deserts on June 21-22 due to high pressure aloft bringing in dry and hot conditions to those areas. Temperatures in the Coachella Valley reached between 114 and 116 and temperatures in the San Diego County Deserts reached 114-115 on June 22. One person died in Ocotillo Wells Recreational State Park due to heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extreme temperatures were observed in the San Diego County deserts as high pressure aloft brought hot and dry conditions to the area. Borrego Springs recorded a high temperature of 114 and Ocotillo Wells reported a high temperature of 115 on June 22. An emergency official reported that one person died in Ocotillo Wells Recreational State Park due to a heat-related illness.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures and sunny skies increased the temperature inside of vehicles and contributed to the heatstroke death of a child in Glendive.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Billings Gazette newspaper reported that a 2 year old male child suffered death by heatstroke hyperthermia after being left in a vehicle through the middle of the day in Glendive on June 26th. The high temperature was 83 degrees, but likely reached 125 degrees inside the enclosed vehicle. Alcohol played a part in this negligent homicide. The boy's body temperature reached 107 degrees and he was removed from life support on June 28th. Link to newspaper article: https://billingsgazette.com/news/crime/glendive-woman-accused-of-negligent-homicide-in-son-s-hot/article_c05d03ea-e68c-50ff-90b0-caea4eba8933.html|.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several days of oppressive heat and humidity were experienced across parts of southern Illinois. The extreme southern tip of the state was impacted the most. Around Metropolis and Cairo, heat indices peaked in the triple digits on five consecutive days. The highest heat indices were observed on the 14th, when values from 110 to 115 were recorded. Areas of southeast Illinois including Fairfield and Mt. Carmel were impacted the least. At Fairfield and Mt. Carmel, heat indices peaked around 105 degrees on the 14th, otherwise heat index readings generally stayed below 100 in that area. High pressure over the Great Lakes region pushed a cold front down into the lower Ohio Valley. Heat indices remained persistently dangerous ahead of the cold front, while slightly lower values infiltrated southeast Illinois.

Several days of oppressive heat and humidity were experienced across southeast Missouri, where heat indices peaked in the triple digits on five consecutive days. The highest heat indices were observed on the 14th, when values from 110 to 115 were recorded along and south of a Sikeston to Poplar Bluff line. Areas north of Cape Girardeau including Perryville were impacted the least. At Perryville, heat indices peaked below 100 degrees on the 12th. Otherwise, heat index readings peaked from 100 to 109 each day at Perryville. High pressure over the Great Lakes region pushed a cold front down into the lower Ohio Valley. Heat indices remained persistently dangerous ahead of the cold front.

Several days of oppressive heat and humidity were experienced across southeast Missouri, where heat indices peaked in the triple digits on five consecutive days. The highest heat indices were observed on the 14th, when values from 110 to 115 were recorded along and south of a Sikeston to Poplar Bluff line. Areas north of Cape Girardeau including Perryville were impacted the least. At Perryville, heat indices peaked below 100 degrees on the 12th. Otherwise, heat index readings peaked from 100 to 109 each day at Perryville. High pressure over the Great Lakes region pushed a cold front down into the lower Ohio Valley. Heat indices remained persistently dangerous ahead of the cold front.

The prolonged period of hazardous heat and humidity that began on June 29th persisted through the first several days of July. The most dangerous heat index values occurred on July 5th, when afternoon heat indices peaked around 110 degrees. Otherwise, the peak heat index each afternoon was near 105. Actual air temperatures were mostly in the lower to mid 90's. South winds ahead of a cold front brought heat and humidity on the 1st. The front stalled over the lower Ohio Valley on the 2nd, then returned northward. Another cold front approached on the 5th, preceded by hot and humid southwest winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A 9-month-old girl died after being left unattended inside a truck for an extensive period of time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A nine-month-old girl died after being left unattended inside a truck for an extended period of time. High temperatures for the day were in the lower 90s. A local observation in La Porte near the time of death reported a temperature of 89 F with a dew point temperature of 74 F that equated to a heat index value of 98 F.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The prolonged period of hazardous heat and humidity that began on June 29th persisted through the first several days of July. The most dangerous heat index values occurred on July 5th, when afternoon heat indices peaked around 110 degrees. Otherwise, the peak heat index was around 105 each day. Actual air temperatures were mostly in the lower to mid 90's, except for some upper 90's on the 5th. South winds ahead of a cold front brought heat and humidity on the 1st. The front stalled over the lower Ohio Valley on the 2nd, then returned northward. Another cold front approached on the 5th, preceded by hot and humid southwest winds.

Several days of oppressive heat and humidity were experienced across parts of southern Illinois. The extreme southern tip of the state was impacted the most. Around Metropolis and Cairo, heat indices peaked in the triple digits on five consecutive days. The highest heat indices were observed on the 14th, when values from 110 to 115 were recorded. Areas of southeast Illinois including Fairfield and Mt. Carmel were impacted the least. At Fairfield and Mt. Carmel, heat indices peaked around 105 degrees on the 14th, otherwise heat index readings generally stayed below 100 in that area. High pressure over the Great Lakes region pushed a cold front down into the lower Ohio Valley. Heat indices remained persistently dangerous ahead of the cold front, while slightly lower values infiltrated southeast Illinois.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid airmass was in place across the region with temperatures in the 90s and dew points in the 60s and 70s.  This resulted in heat index values reaching 100 to 110 degrees during the afternoon hours in valley areas. ||This hot and humid air mass also provided an unstable environment for strong to severe thunderstorms to form ahead of a cold front passage during the afternoon and evening hours of June 18th. The storms caused numerous trees and power lines to be knocked down, resulting in over 10,000 customers without power. A vacant historic building in Poughkeepsie, New York partially collapsed onto an occupied building, trapping and injuring one woman.
There was widespread unseasonable heat across the Central Valley over a period of 3 days, with triple digit high temperatures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The NWS Experimental HeatRisk reached High readings that prompted a heat warning  for the northern Sacramento Valley. PG&E activated their Emergency Operations Center in support of the June Heat Event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There was widespread unseasonable heat across the Central Valley over a period of 3 days, with triple digit high temperatures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The NWS Experimental HeatRisk reached High readings that prompted a heat warning  for the central Sacramento Valley. PG&E activated their Emergency Operations Center in support of the June Heat Event.

High pressure to our south caused a west to southwest wind, resulting in humid conditions while subsidence from an upper-level ridge led to hot conditions. The combination of hot and humid conditions led to heat indices around 100 to 105 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices were around 100 degrees at the Hagerstown Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure to our south caused a west to southwest wind, resulting in humid conditions while subsidence from an upper-level ridge led to hot conditions. The combination of hot and humid conditions led to heat indices around 100 to 105 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices were estimated to be around 105 degrees based on observations nearby.

A hot and humid airmass was in place across the region with temperatures in the 90s and dew points in the 60s and 70s.  This resulted in heat index values reaching 100 to 110 degrees during the afternoon hours in valley areas. ||This hot and humid air mass also provided an unstable environment for strong to severe thunderstorms to form ahead of a cold front passage during the afternoon and evening hours of June 18th. The month of June closed with one of the hottest days in recent memory. Highs were well into the 90s, including 99 at Alpena, and 98 at Traverse City and Gaylord. The National Weather Service office near Gaylord also hit 98; that was (by several degrees) the warmest reading recorded at that location since observations began there in the late 1990s. Heat indices exceeded 105 degrees across most of northern lower Michigan, and some locations exceed 110. The warmest reported heat index on the day was 114 near Indian River. There were estimated to be between 25 and 30 individuals who visited local hospitals due to heat-related illnesses.

Two 6 month old infants were left in a hot vehicle at the 2400 block of Alfalfa Lane, near Jefferson Davis Highway just south of Richmond Virginia. They were transported to a hospital. One died almost immediately, while the other was initially in critical condition, but then later died.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two 6 month old infants were left in a hot vehicle at the 2400 block of Alfalfa Lane, near Jefferson Davis Highway just south of Richmond Virginia. They were transported to a hospital. One died almost immediately, while the other was initially in critical condition, but then later died.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid airmass brought excessively high heat indices to eastern New York from the beginning of July through the Independence Day holiday. Temperatures soared as high as 99 degrees on July 1st, the hottest day of the stretch. Combined with dewpoints in the mid-70s, heat indices reached near 110 degrees in the warmest valleys. July 5th marked the sixth consecutive day reaching a temperature of 90 degrees at Albany and Glens Falls, and a seventh consecutive day at Poughkeepsie. In addition to the hot daytime temperatures, overnight low temperatures only falling into the 70s was common, which exacerbated heat-related problems. The extensive heat prompted the opening of many cooling centers across the region.

It was hot and humid on July 16th as temperatures soared into the low to mid-90s with dewpoints in the upper 60s to low 70s in the Hudson and Mohawk Valleys. This resulted in heat indices reaching the mid to upper 90s. Isolated, slow-moving thunderstorms developed during the afternoon in the hot air, one of which resulted in wind damage and flash flooding in Ulster County.

June ended with two days of excessive heat across northeast Iowa. Heat indices topped out between 105 and 110 on both June 29th and 30th, although the high heat indices were more widespread on the 29th. Air temperatures in the upper 80s to middle 90s with dew points in the middle 70s combined to create the excessive heat. The highest calculated heat index was 111 from a mesonet station in McGregor (Clayton County).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices of 105 to 110 were common across Winneshiek County on June 29th and 30th. The highest calculated heat index was 110 from a mesonet station northwest of Frankville. Decorah had a peak heat index of 104.

In addition to the hot daytime temperatures, overnight low temperatures only falling into the 70s was common, which exacerbated heat-related problems. The extensive heat prompted the opening of many cooling centers across the region.

A hot and humid airmass brought excessively high heat indices to eastern New York from the beginning of July through the Independence Day holiday. In addition to the hot daytime temperatures, overnight low temperatures only falling into the 70s was common, which exacerbated heat-related problems. The extensive heat prompted the opening of many cooling centers across the region.

It was hot and humid on July 16th as temperatures soared into the low to mid-90s with dewpoints in the upper 60s to low 70s in the Hudson and Mohawk Valleys. This resulted in heat indices reaching the mid to upper 90s. Isolated, slow-moving thunderstorms developed during the afternoon in the hot air, one of which resulted in wind damage and flash flooding in Ulster County.

The month of June closed with one of the hottest days in recent memory. Highs were well into the 90s, including 99 at Alpena, and 98 at Traverse City and Gaylord. The National Weather Service office near Gaylord also hit 98; that was (by several degrees) the warmest reading recorded at that location since observations began there in the late 1990s. Heat indices exceeded 105 degrees across most of northern lower Michigan, and some locations exceed 110. The warmest reported heat index on the day was 114 near Indian River. There were estimated to be between 25 and 30 individuals who visited local hospitals due to heat-related illnesses.

Strong high pressure settled over South Central Texas, and temperatures soared to record levels. The heat wave started on the 19th in Burnet, Frio, Llano, Medina, Travis, and Williamson Counties with high temperatures reaching 105 and higher. The hot temperatures spread across the region, reaching their greatest extent on the 23rd when 22 counties reached extreme heat criteria. During this time Austin Bergstrom International Airport had record highs each day from the 20th through the 23rd, Austin Camp Mabry 21-23, and San Antonio 22-23. Both Austin sites set the all-time record high for the month on the 23rd, Bergstrom 109 and Camp Mabry 110. The extreme heat broke on the 24th when highs dropped down closer to 100.

The heat wave started on the 19th in Burnet, Frio, Llano, Medina, Travis, and Williamson Counties with high temperatures reaching 105 and higher. The hot temperatures spread across the region reaching its greatest extent on the 23rd. During this time Austin Bergstrom International Airport had record highs each day from the 20th through the 23rd, Austin Camp Mabry 21-23, and San Antonio 22-23. Both Austin sites set the all-time record high for the month on the 23rd, Bergstrom 109 and Camp Mabry 110. The extreme heat broke on the 24th when highs dropped down closer to 100.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Emergency Medical Services Authority (EMSA) issued a heat alert for Oklahoma City Metro after receiving 5 heat related emergency calls. Maximum temperatures reached to about 96 degrees with a heat index of 102 degrees Fahrenheit.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat injuries inferred from number of calls to EMSA.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The month of June closed with one of the hottest days in recent memory. Highs were well into the 90s, including 99 at Alpena, and 98 at Traverse City and Gaylord. The National Weather Service office near Gaylord also hit 98; that was (by several degrees) the warmest reading recorded at that location since observations began there in the late 1990s. Heat indices exceeded 105 degrees across most of northern lower Michigan, and some locations exceed 110. The warmest reported heat index on the day was 114 near Indian River. There were estimated to be between 25 and 30 individuals who visited local hospitals due to heat-related illnesses.

High pressure over the region led to a stretch of hot day July 12 through July 17th. Hot temperatures led people to cool off in local rivers. There were two drownings recorded on July 16 and July 18.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures on July 16th near the Sandy River in Troutdale got up to 98 degrees, the day a swimmer went underwater in the Sandy River near Glen Otto Community Park. He later died in the hospital.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over the region led to a stretch of hot day July 12 through July 17th. Hot temperatures led people to cool off in local rivers. There were two drownings recorded on July 16 and July 18.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A man swimming across the Willamette River from Yamhill County to Marion County near the Wheatland Ferry drowned. It had been hot the previous several days, and though temperatures were a bit cooler on the 18th with highs only in the upper 80s, it's believed that the heat over the previous several days led him to swim in the river that day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: It was hot and humid on July 16th as temperatures soared into the low to mid-90s with dewpoints in the upper 60s to low 70s in the Hudson and Mohawk Valleys. This resulted in heat indices reaching the mid to upper 90s. Isolated, slow-moving thunderstorms developed during the afternoon in the hot air, one of which resulted in wind damage and flash flooding in Ulster County.

Heat index values reached 105 degrees in northwest Alabama during the afternoon of the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The heat index reached up to 107 degrees.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The heat index reached up to 107 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Afternoon heat indices peaked around 105 degrees across parts of southeast Missouri, mainly along and southeast of a line from Cape Girardeau to Poplar Bluff. Southwest winds ahead of a cold front brought hot and humid air. Daytime high temperatures were in the lower to mid 90's, accompanied by high humidity.

Southwest winds ahead of a cold front brought hot and humid air. Daytime high temperatures were in the lower to mid 90's, accompanied by high humidity.

High pressure aloft brought in dry and hot conditions to the deserts from June 3rd through 5th. Extreme heat was observed in the Coachella Valley and San Diego County Deserts, and one person died from a heat-related illness.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High pressure aloft brought in dry conditions and extreme temperatures to the Coachella Valley on June 3-5. Temperatures reached 113 in Palm Springs and Thermal on the 3rd and 4th, and decreased to 104 on the 5th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure aloft brought in dry and hot conditions to the deserts from June 3rd through 5th. Extreme heat was observed in the Coachella Valley and San Diego County Deserts, and one person died from a heat-related illness.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High pressure aloft brought in dry conditions and extreme temperatures to the San Diego County deserts from June 3-5. Ocotillo Wells reported temperatures of 111 on June 3 and 110 on June 4. One man died on June 4th from a heat-related illness.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure expanded east from the Oklahoma/Texas Panhandle region into the middle Red River Valley of Southeast Oklahoma, Southwest Arkansas, and Northeast Texas during June 28th and 29th. Very dry conditions due to the developing drought conditions across Southeast Oklahoma combined with the compressional warming beneath the ridge resulted in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid and upper 90s  each day. Limited mixing was also observed each day, with resultant heat indices ranging between 105 and 110 degrees.

Limited mixing was also observed each day, with resultant heat indices ranging between 105 and 110 degrees.
There was widespread unseasonable heat across the Central Valley over a period of 3 days, with triple digit high temperatures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The NWS Experimental HeatRisk reached High readings that prompted a heat warning  for the southern Sacramento Valley. PG&E activated their Emergency Operations Center in support of the June Heat Event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There was widespread unseasonable heat across the Central Valley over a period of 3 days, with triple digit high temperatures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The NWS Experimental HeatRisk reached High readings that prompted a heat warning  for the northern San Joaquin Valley. PG&E activated their Emergency Operations Center in support of the June Heat Event.

Several days of oppressive heat and humidity were experienced across southeast Missouri, where heat indices peaked in the triple digits on five consecutive days. The highest heat indices were observed on the 14th, when values from 110 to 115 were recorded along and south of a Sikeston to Poplar Bluff line. Areas north of Cape Girardeau including Perryville were impacted the least. At Perryville, heat indices peaked below 100 degrees on the 12th. Otherwise, heat index readings peaked from 100 to 109 each day at Perryville. High pressure over the Great Lakes region pushed a cold front down into the lower Ohio Valley. Heat indices remained persistently dangerous ahead of the cold front.

Areas north of Cape Girardeau including Perryville were impacted the least. At Perryville, heat indices peaked below 100 degrees on the 12th. Otherwise, heat index readings peaked from 100 to 109 each day at Perryville. High pressure over the Great Lakes region pushed a cold front down into the lower Ohio Valley. Heat indices remained persistently dangerous ahead of the cold front.

The prolonged period of hazardous heat and humidity that began on June 29th persisted through the first several days of July. The most dangerous heat index values occurred on July 5th, when afternoon heat indices peaked from 110 to 115 degrees. Otherwise, the peak heat index was from 105 to 110 on the 4th, and near 105 on the 1st, 2nd, and 3rd. Actual air temperatures were mostly in the mid to upper 90's. South winds ahead of a cold front brought heat and humidity on the 1st. The front stalled over the lower Ohio Valley on the 2nd, then returned northward. Another cold front approached on the 5th, preceded by hot and humid southwest winds.

Otherwise, the peak heat index was from 105 to 110 on the 4th, and near 105 on the 1st, 2nd, and 3rd. Actual air temperatures were mostly in the mid to upper 90's. South winds ahead of a cold front brought heat and humidity on the 1st. The front stalled over the lower Ohio Valley on the 2nd, then returned northward. Another cold front approached on the 5th, preceded by hot and humid southwest winds.

Peak afternoon heat index values reached 100 to 105 for three consecutive days in the City of Chicago and Cook County from June 16th to June 18th.  High temperatures on June 16th were 92 at O'Hare Airport, 93 at Midway Airport and 84 at Northerly Island.  High temperatures on June 17th were 93 at O'Hare Airport, 95 at Midway Airport and 93 at Northerly Island.  High temperatures on June 18th were 95 at O'Hare Airport, 95 at Midway Airport and 93 at Northerly Island.

An upper level ridge of high pressure expanded east from the Oklahoma/Texas Panhandle region into the middle Red River Valley of Southeast Oklahoma, Southwest Arkansas, and Northeast Texas during June 28th and 29th. Very dry conditions due to the developing drought conditions across Southwest Arkansas combined with the compressional warming beneath the ridge resulted in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid and upper 90s  each day. Limited mixing was also observed each day, with resultant heat indices ranging between 105 and 110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Oppressive heat and humidity was experienced across southwest Indiana, where heat indices peaked around 105 degrees. Actual air temperatures reached the mid 90's. The heat and humidity built up on the back side of a high pressure center over the middle Atlantic coast.

Several days of oppressive heat and humidity were experienced across parts of southern Illinois. The extreme southern tip of the state was impacted the most. Around Metropolis and Cairo, heat indices peaked in the triple digits on five consecutive days. The highest heat indices were observed on the 14th, when values from 110 to 115 were recorded. Areas of southeast Illinois including Fairfield and Mt. Carmel were impacted the least. At Fairfield and Mt. Carmel, heat indices peaked around 105 degrees on the 14th, otherwise heat index readings generally stayed below 100 in that area. High pressure over the Great Lakes region pushed a cold front down into the lower Ohio Valley. Heat indices remained persistently dangerous ahead of the cold front, while slightly lower values infiltrated southeast Illinois.

Very hot and humid conditions developed across northern Illinois on June 29th and June 30th and these conditions continued into July 1st.  ||For June 29th, in Cook County, O'Hare Airport reached a high temperature of 96 with a peak heat index of 106; Midway Airport reached a high temperature of 95 with a peak heat index of 109 and Lansing Airport reached a high temperature of 91 with a peak heat index of 111.  In Dupage County, West Chicago Airport reached a high temperature of 93 with a peak heat index of 110.  In Will County, Joliet Airport reached a high temperature of 93 with a peak heat index of 114 and The Midewin Tallgrass Prairie reached a high temperature of 93 with a peak heat index of 116.  In LaSalle County, Peru Airport reached a high temperature of 94 with a peak heat index of 114.  In Livingston County, Pontiac Airport reached a high temperature of 92 with a peak heat index of 115. An upper level ridge of high pressure expanded east from the Oklahoma/Texas Panhandle region into the middle Red River Valley of Southeast Oklahoma, Southwest Arkansas, Northeast Texas, and North Louisiana during June 29th. Very dry conditions due to the developing drought conditions across North Louisiana combined with the compressional warming beneath the ridge resulted in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid 90s to near 100 degrees. Limited mixing was also observed, with resultant heat indices ranging between 105 and 110 degrees.

A large middle and upper level ridge of high pressure expanded south from the Midwest into much of the Ark-La-Tex during July 13th. Very dry conditions due to the ongoing drought conditions across much of the region combined with the compressional warming beneath the ridge resulted in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid 90s areawide. Limited mixing was also observed, with resultant heat indices ranging between 105 and 110 degrees.

The Emergency Medical Services Authority (EMSA) issued a heat alert for Oklahoma City Metro 2nd which continued through the 25th. Over this time period EMSA received 185 heat related calls. Maximum temperatures ranged from about 90 degrees to about 110 degrees Fahrenheit.

Residing just south of a frontal boundary, a very warm and humid air mass brought dangerous heat indices to much of southeast South Dakota.  Afternoon temperatures climbed to 90 to 95 degrees and combined with dew point readings in the mid to upper 70's to result in heat index values from 100-105.

Just south of an outflow from morning convection, sunshine returned temperatures to around 90 degrees, with stifling dew point readings near 80 degrees. Heat index values reached 100-105 for several hours during the early to mid afternoon, before the outflow expanded to cool readings below advisory criteria.

Heat index values reached 100-105 for several hours during the early to mid afternoon, before the outflow expanded to cool readings below advisory criteria.

A heat wave with unusually persistent hot and humid conditions occurred across the region from July 2nd through the 5th. Temperatures in the upper 80s and 90s along with dewpoints in the 70s produced heat index readings generally ranging through the 90s. During this time...heat related emergency room visits and requests for ambulance transport increased. The greatest heat related health impacts occurred with adults aged 65 and older. However...no deaths were considered directly attributable to the heat. A cold front crossing the region during the 6th broke the heat wave.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Maximum Heat Index values generally ranged through the 90s during the heat wave.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of high pressure strengthened over the region on July 17 resulting a long stretch of days with 100 degree and warmer days across the San Joaquin Valley and the Kern County Deserts. The high strengthened over California on July 24. This resulted in several days of excessive heat over the Kern County Deserts where and Excessive Heat Warning was issued for a five day period, and a significant heat wave persisted across the San Joaquin Valley where emergency cooling centers were opened each afternoon in several municipalities between July 24 and July 28. Heat Advisories were posted for the San Joaquin Valley as well as for the lower elevations of the southern Sierra foothills and Kern County Mountains during this period. The high finally weakened on July 29 and 30 which allowed for temperatures to finally cool down closer to normal levels. The month turned out to be the warmest July on record for Fresno and the second warmest on record for Bakersfield.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 102 and 108 degrees at most locations between July 24 and July 28.

During this time...heat related emergency room visits and requests for ambulance transport increased. The greatest heat related health impacts occurred with adults aged 65 and older. However...no deaths were considered directly attributable to the heat. A cold front crossing the region during the 6th broke the heat wave.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Maximum Heat Index values generally ranged through the 90s during the heat wave.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late-season heat wave impacted eastern New York during the first week of September. A persistent warm and moist airmass characterized by daytime highs in the 90s and dewpoints in the 70s resulted in heat index values reaching 95-105 degrees during the afternoon hours. Daily record high temperatures were set or tied at Albany on the 5th and 6th, and a daily record high minimum temperature was set on the 3rd. This heat wave coincided with the first week of school for many, and the heat prompted some schools to dismiss classes early and postpone or cancel sports practices.

A large middle and upper level ridge of high pressure expanded south from the Midwest into much of the Ark-La-Tex during July 13th. Very dry conditions due to the ongoing drought conditions across much of the region combined with the compressional warming beneath the ridge resulted in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid 90s areawide. Limited mixing was also observed, with resultant heat indices ranging between 105 and 110 degrees.

A large mid and upper level ridge of high pressure expanded from the Southern Rockies across all of the Ark-La-Tex during July 19th-23rd. Very dry conditions due to the ongoing drought conditions across much of East Texas combined with the compressional warming beneath the ridge resulted in afternoon temperatures ranging from 100-107 degrees each day. Limited mixing was also observed, with resultant and oppressive heat indices ranging between 105 to 110 degrees on the 19th-21st. A cold front slowly shifted southwest across Northeast Texas on July 22nd, with additional compressional warming along and just south of the front resulting in near record heat for the month of July with temperatures near or in excess of 105 degrees, and oppressively high heat indices ranging from 110 to 115 degrees. The pre-frontal compressional warming continued on the 23rd, with ambient air temperatures ranging from 100 to 105 degrees, and heat indices ranging from 106 to 112 degrees. Slightly cooler and drier air spilled southwest across the remainder of East Texas in wake of the frontal passage late in the day on the 23rd.

Very hot temperatures occurred in Tucson and the deserts west of Tucson on July 5th.  The record high temperature was tied at the Tucson International Airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures between 108 and 113 were common from Tucson westward across Pima County and in southwest Pinal County. A record high temperature of 111 degrees was tied at the Tucson International Airport. Sells reached 113 degrees and Ajo topped out at 109 degrees.

Temperatures in the upper 80s and 90s along with dewpoints in the 70s produced heat index readings generally ranging through the 90s. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Maximum Heat Index values generally ranged through the 90s during the heat wave.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid airmass brought excessively high heat indices to eastern New York from the beginning of July through the Independence Day holiday. Temperatures soared as high as 99 degrees on July 1st, the hottest day of the stretch. Combined with dewpoints in the mid-70s, heat indices reached near 110 degrees in the warmest valleys. July 5th marked the sixth consecutive day reaching a temperature of 90 degrees at Albany and Glens Falls, and a seventh consecutive day at Poughkeepsie. In addition to the hot daytime temperatures, overnight low temperatures only falling into the 70s was common, which exacerbated heat-related problems. The extensive heat prompted the opening of many cooling centers across the region.

A hot and humid airmass brought excessively high heat indices to western Massachusetts during the beginning of July. Temperatures soared as high as the mid to upper 90s on July 1st, the hottest day of the stretch. Combined with dewpoints in the mid-70s, heat indices reached near 105 degrees in the warmest areas. July 4th marked the fourth consecutive day with a high temperature in the 90s at Pittsfield. In addition to the hot daytime temperatures, overnight low temperatures only falling into the 70s was common, which exacerbated heat-related problems. The extensive heat prompted the opening of many cooling centers across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures occurred in the valleys of southeast Arizona from July 23rd through July 25th.  Several record high temperatures were observed. While no fatalities occurred, several reports of heat-related illnesses were noted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessively hot temperatures of 108 to 113 degrees were observed below 4000 feet in southeast Arizona.  The high temperature record at the Tucson International Airport were tied on July 23 with 109 degrees and broken on the 24th and 25th with highs of 112 and 110 degrees, respectively. Tucson Fire, responded to at least six heat-related calls on July 24th.  On July 23rd, the Safford Airport reached 112 degrees and San Simon topped out at 108. A temperature of 111 degrees was attained at Sells on July 25th and at Ajo on both the 24th and 25th. Benson reached 110 on all three days.  Record highs were set at Bisbee-Douglas Airport on the 23rd and 24th with 105 and 104 degrees, respectively.

Residing just south of a frontal boundary, a very warm and humid air mass brought dangerous heat indices to much of southeast South Dakota.  Afternoon temperatures climbed to 90 to 95 degrees and combined with dew point readings in the mid to upper 70's to result in heat index values from 100-105.

A Bermuda high pumped in heat and high humidity across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The AWOS at Chester reported heat indices of 105 to 109 during the afternoon hours.

A 3-year-old boy died after being left unattended for at least four hours in a hot vehicle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A three-year-old boy died after being left unattended for at least four hours in a hot vehicle. Law enforcement said the temperature inside the vehicle was at least 113 degrees.

Several days of oppressive heat and humidity were experienced across parts of west Kentucky. The extreme western end of the state was impacted the most. From Paducah south and west, heat indices peaked in the triple digits on five consecutive days. The highest heat indices were observed on the 14th, when values from 110 to 115 were recorded. Areas of northwest Kentucky including Owensboro and Henderson were impacted the least. At Owensboro and Henderson, heat indices peaked around 105 degrees on the 14th. Otherwise, heat index readings generally stayed below 100 in northwest Kentucky. High pressure over the Great Lakes region pushed a cold front down into the lower Ohio Valley. Heat indices remained persistently dangerous ahead of the cold front, while slightly lower values infiltrated northwest Kentucky.

The prolonged period of hazardous heat and humidity that began on June 29th persisted through the first several days of July. The most dangerous heat index values occurred on July 5th, when afternoon heat indices peaked around 110 degrees. Otherwise, the peak heat index each afternoon was near 105. Actual air temperatures were mostly in the lower to mid 90's. South winds ahead of a cold front brought heat and humidity on the 1st. The front stalled over the lower Ohio Valley on the 2nd, then returned northward. Another cold front approached on the 5th, preceded by hot and humid southwest winds.

The front stalled over the lower Ohio Valley on the 2nd, then returned northward. Another cold front approached on the 5th, preceded by hot and humid southwest winds.

A large middle and upper level ridge of high pressure expanded south from the Midwest into much of the Ark-La-Tex during July 13th. Very dry conditions due to the ongoing drought conditions across much of the region combined with the compressional warming beneath the ridge resulted in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid 90s areawide. Limited mixing was also observed, with resultant heat indices ranging between 105 and 110 degrees.

A large mid and upper level ridge of high pressure expanded from the Southern Rockies across all of the Ark-La-Tex during July 19th-23rd. Very dry conditions due to the ongoing drought conditions across much of East Texas combined with the compressional warming beneath the ridge resulted in afternoon temperatures ranging from 100-107 degrees each day. Limited mixing was also observed, with resultant and oppressive heat indices ranging between 105 to 110 degrees on the 19th-21st. A cold front slowly shifted southwest across Northeast Texas on July 22nd, with additional compressional warming along and just south of the front resulting in near record heat for the month of July with temperatures near or in excess of 105 degrees, and oppressively high heat indices ranging from 110 to 115 degrees. The pre-frontal compressional warming continued on the 23rd, with ambient air temperatures ranging from 100 to 105 degrees, and heat indices ranging from 106 to 112 degrees. Slightly cooler and drier air spilled southwest across the remainder of East Texas in wake of the frontal passage late in the day on the 23rd.

Very dry conditions due to the ongoing drought conditions across Northcentral Louisiana combined with the compressional warming beneath the ridge resulted in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid to upper 90s. Strong high pressure coupled with very dry air brought very hot temperatures to the area during this interval.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Low temperatures in this zone ranged from 52 to 62 degrees and high temperatures ranged from 92 to 108 degrees during this interval.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several days of oppressive heat and humidity were experienced across parts of west Kentucky. The extreme western end of the state was impacted the most. From Paducah south and west, heat indices peaked in the triple digits on five consecutive days. The highest heat indices were observed on the 14th, when values from 110 to 115 were recorded. Areas of northwest Kentucky including Owensboro and Henderson were impacted the least. At Owensboro and Henderson, heat indices peaked around 105 degrees on the 14th. Otherwise, heat index readings generally stayed below 100 in northwest Kentucky. High pressure over the Great Lakes region pushed a cold front down into the lower Ohio Valley. Heat indices remained persistently dangerous ahead of the cold front, while slightly lower values infiltrated northwest Kentucky.

From Paducah south and west, heat indices peaked in the triple digits on five consecutive days. The highest heat indices were observed on the 14th, when values from 110 to 115 were recorded. Areas of northwest Kentucky including Owensboro and Henderson were impacted the least. At Owensboro and Henderson, heat indices peaked around 105 degrees on the 14th. Otherwise, heat index readings generally stayed below 100 in northwest Kentucky. High pressure over the Great Lakes region pushed a cold front down into the lower Ohio Valley. Heat indices remained persistently dangerous ahead of the cold front, while slightly lower values infiltrated northwest Kentucky.

A late-season heat wave impacted eastern New York during the first week of September. A persistent warm and moist airmass characterized by daytime highs in the 90s and dewpoints in the 70s resulted in heat index values reaching 95-105 degrees during the afternoon hours. Daily record high temperatures were set or tied at Albany on the 5th and 6th, and a daily record high minimum temperature was set on the 3rd. This heat wave coincided with the first week of school for many, and the heat prompted some schools to dismiss classes early and postpone or cancel sports practices.

A persistent warm and moist airmass characterized by daytime highs in the 90s and dewpoints in the 70s resulted in heat index values reaching 95-105 degrees during the afternoon hours. Daily record high temperatures were set or tied at Albany on the 5th and 6th, and a daily record high minimum temperature was set on the 3rd. This heat wave coincided with the first week of school for many, and the heat prompted some schools to dismiss classes early and postpone or cancel sports practices.

A late-season heat wave impacted southern Vermont during the first week of September. A persistent warm and moist airmass characterized by daytime highs in the upper 80s to low 90s and dewpoints in the 70s resulted in heat index values reaching 90-100 degrees during the afternoon hours. This heat wave coincided with the first week of school for many, and the heat prompted some schools to dismiss classes early and postpone or cancel sports practices.

A late-season heat wave impacted northwestern Connecticut during the first week of September. A persistent warm and moist airmass characterized by daytime highs in the 90s and dewpoints in the 70s resulted in heat index values reaching 95-105 degrees during the afternoon hours. This heat wave coincided with the first week of school for many, and the heat prompted some schools to cancel or dismiss classes early and postpone or cancel sports practices.

Several days of oppressive heat and humidity were experienced across parts of west Kentucky. The extreme western end of the state was impacted the most. From Paducah south and west, heat indices peaked in the triple digits on five consecutive days. The highest heat indices were observed on the 14th, when values from 110 to 115 were recorded. Areas of northwest Kentucky including Owensboro and Henderson were impacted the least. At Owensboro and Henderson, heat indices peaked around 105 degrees on the 14th. Otherwise, heat index readings generally stayed below 100 in northwest Kentucky. High pressure over the Great Lakes region pushed a cold front down into the lower Ohio Valley. Heat indices remained persistently dangerous ahead of the cold front, while slightly lower values infiltrated northwest Kentucky.

The prolonged period of hazardous heat and humidity that began on June 29th persisted through the first several days of July. The most dangerous heat index values occurred on July 5th, when afternoon heat indices peaked around 110 degrees. Otherwise, the peak heat index each afternoon was near 105. Actual air temperatures were mostly in the lower to mid 90's. South winds ahead of a cold front brought heat and humidity on the 1st. The front stalled over the lower Ohio Valley on the 2nd, then returned northward. Another cold front approached on the 5th, preceded by hot and humid southwest winds.

An upper level ridge of high pressure expanded east from the Four Corners Region into Southeast Oklahoma, Northeast Texas, Southwest Arkansas, and North Louisiana during July 15th and 16th. Very dry conditions due to the ongoing drought conditions across Northcentral Louisiana combined with the compressional warming beneath the ridge resulted in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid to upper 90s. Limited mixing was also observed, with resultant heat indices ranging between 105 and 110 degrees both days.

Very hot and humid conditions developed across northern Illinois on June 29th and June 30th and these conditions continued into July 1st.  In Livingston County, Pontiac Airport reached a high temperature of 91 with a peak heat index of 112.  In Cook County, O'Hare Airport reached a high temperature of 94 with a peak heat index of 101; Midway Airport reached a high temperature of 94 with a peak heat index of 105 and Lansing Airport reached a high temperature of 91 with a peak heat index of 106.

An upper level ridge of high pressure expanded east from the Four Corners Region into Southeast Oklahoma, Northeast Texas, Southwest Arkansas, and North Louisiana during July 16th. Very dry conditions due to the ongoing drought conditions across Northwest Louisiana combined with the compressional warming beneath the ridge resulted in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid to upper 90s. Limited mixing was also observed, with resultant heat indices ranging between 105 and 110 degrees both days.

A large mid and upper level ridge of high pressure expanded from the Southern Rockies across all of the Ark-La-Tex during July 19th-21st. Very dry conditions due to the ongoing drought conditions across Southeast Oklahoma combined with the compressional warming beneath the ridge resulted in afternoon temperatures ranging from 104-108 degrees each day across all of McCurtain County. Limited mixing was also observed, with resultant and oppressive heat indices ranging between 110 and 115 degrees each day as well.

A large mid and upper level ridge of high pressure expanded from the Southern Rockies across all of the Ark-La-Tex during July 19th-22nd. Very dry conditions due to the ongoing drought conditions across much of North Louisiana combined with the compressional warming beneath the ridge resulted in afternoon temperatures ranging from 100-108 degrees each day. Limited mixing was also observed, with resultant and oppressive heat indices ranging between 106 to 112 degrees on the 19th-21st. A cold front slowly shifted southwest across North Louisiana on July 22nd, with additional compressional warming along and just south of the front resulting in the hottest temperatures for the month of July on record in Shreveport, with oppressively high heat indices ranging from 110 to 116 degrees. Slightly cooler and drier air spilled southwest across North Louisiana in wake of the frontal passage on the 23rd.
High temperatures were in the mid 90s with heat index values around 105 in the St. Louis metro area. Eight people were admitted to local hospitals for heat related illnesses.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures were in the mid 90s with heat index values around 105 in the St. Louis metro area. Four people were admitted to local hospitals for heat related illnesses in the City of St. Louis.

A large mid and upper level ridge of high pressure expanded from the Southern Rockies across all of the Ark-La-Tex during July 19th-22nd. Very dry conditions due to the ongoing drought conditions across much of North Louisiana combined with the compressional warming beneath the ridge resulted in afternoon temperatures ranging from 100-108 degrees each day. Limited mixing was also observed, with resultant and oppressive heat indices ranging between 106 to 112 degrees on the 19th-21st. A cold front slowly shifted southwest across North Louisiana on July 22nd, with additional compressional warming along and just south of the front resulting in the hottest temperatures for the month of July on record in Shreveport, with oppressively high heat indices ranging from 110 to 116 degrees. Slightly cooler and drier air spilled southwest across North Louisiana in wake of the frontal passage on the 23rd.

Limited mixing was also observed, with resultant and oppressive heat indices ranging between 106 to 112 degrees on the 19th-21st. A large mid and upper level ridge of high pressure expanded from the Southern Rockies across all of the Ark-La-Tex during July 19th-23rd. Very dry conditions due to the ongoing drought conditions across much of North Louisiana combined with the compressional warming beneath the ridge resulted in afternoon temperatures ranging from 100-108 degrees each day. Limited mixing was also observed, with resultant and oppressive heat indices ranging between 106 to 112 degrees on the 19th-21st. A cold front slowly shifted southwest across North Louisiana on July 22nd, with additional compressional warming along and just south of the front resulting in near record heat for the month of July with temperatures near or in excess of 105 degrees, and oppressively high heat indices ranging from 107 to 114 degrees. The pre-frontal compressional warming continued on the 23rd, with ambient air temperatures in the mid to upper 90s, and heat indices ranging from 105 to 107 degrees. Slightly cooler and drier air spilled southwest across Westcentral Louisiana in wake of the frontal passage late in the day on the 23rd.

A large mid and upper level ridge of high pressure expanded from the Southern Rockies across all of the Ark-La-Tex during July 19th-21st. Very dry conditions due to the ongoing drought conditions across much of Northeast Texas combined with the compressional warming beneath the ridge resulted in afternoon temperatures ranging from 100-104 degrees each day. Limited mixing was also observed, with resultant heat indices ranging between 105 to 110 degrees. A cold front slowly shifted southwest across extreme Northeast Texas during the overnight hours of July 21st-22nd, with slightly cooler and drier air spreading south behind the front.

A large mid and upper level ridge of high pressure expanded from the Southern Rockies across all of the Ark-La-Tex during July 19th-21st. Very dry conditions due to the ongoing drought conditions across much of Northeast Texas combined with the compressional warming beneath the ridge resulted in afternoon temperatures ranging from 100-104 degrees each day. Limited mixing was also observed, with resultant heat indices ranging between 105 to 110 degrees. A cold front slowly shifted southwest across extreme Northeast Texas during the overnight hours of July 21st-22nd, with slightly cooler and drier air spreading south behind the front.

Very dry conditions due to the ongoing drought conditions across much of Northeast Texas combined with the compressional warming beneath the ridge resulted in afternoon temperatures ranging from 100-105 degrees each day. Limited mixing was also observed, with resultant heat indices ranging between 105 to 110 degrees each day. A cold front slowly shifted southwest across Northeast Texas during the morning hours of July 22nd, which brought about slightly cooler temperatures and drier air into the area.

A large mid and upper level ridge of high pressure expanded from the Southern Rockies across all of the Ark-La-Tex during July 19th-23rd. Very dry conditions due to the ongoing drought conditions across much of East Texas combined with the compressional warming beneath the ridge resulted in afternoon temperatures ranging from 100-107 degrees each day. Limited mixing was also observed, with resultant and oppressive heat indices ranging between 105 to 110 degrees on the 19th-21st. A cold front slowly shifted southwest across Northeast Texas on July 22nd, with additional compressional warming along and just south of the front resulting in near record heat for the month of July with temperatures near or in excess of 105 degrees, and oppressively high heat indices ranging from 110 to 115 degrees. The pre-frontal compressional warming continued on the 23rd, with ambient air temperatures ranging from 100 to 105 degrees, and heat indices ranging from 106 to 112 degrees. Slightly cooler and drier air spilled southwest across the remainder of East Texas in wake of the frontal passage late in the day on the 23rd.

Several days of oppressive heat and humidity were experienced across parts of west Kentucky. The extreme western end of the state was impacted the most. From Paducah south and west, heat indices peaked in the triple digits on five consecutive days. The highest heat indices were observed on the 14th, when values from 110 to 115 were recorded. Areas of northwest Kentucky including Owensboro and Henderson were impacted the least. At Owensboro and Henderson, heat indices peaked around 105 degrees on the 14th. Otherwise, heat index readings generally stayed below 100 in northwest Kentucky. High pressure over the Great Lakes region pushed a cold front down into the lower Ohio Valley. Heat indices remained persistently dangerous ahead of the cold front, while slightly lower values infiltrated northwest Kentucky.

Several days of oppressive heat and humidity were experienced across parts of southern Illinois. The extreme southern tip of the state was impacted the most. Around Metropolis and Cairo, heat indices peaked in the triple digits on five consecutive days. The highest heat indices were observed on the 14th, when values from 110 to 115 were recorded. Areas of southeast Illinois including Fairfield and Mt. Carmel were impacted the least. At Fairfield and Mt. Carmel, heat indices peaked around 105 degrees on the 14th, otherwise heat index readings generally stayed below 100 in that area. High pressure over the Great Lakes region pushed a cold front down into the lower Ohio Valley. Heat indices remained persistently dangerous ahead of the cold front, while slightly lower values infiltrated southeast Illinois.

The prolonged period of hazardous heat and humidity that began on June 29th persisted through the first several days of July. The most dangerous heat index values occurred on July 5th, when afternoon heat indices peaked around 110 degrees. Otherwise, the peak heat index each afternoon was near 105. Actual air temperatures were mostly in the lower to mid 90's. South winds ahead of a cold front brought heat and humidity on the 1st. The front stalled over the lower Ohio Valley on the 2nd, then returned northward. Another cold front approached on the 5th, preceded by hot and humid southwest winds.

CZ_NAME: UPPER SANTA CRUZ RIVER AND ALTAR VALLEYS
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures occurred in the valleys of southeast Arizona from July 23rd through July 25th.  Several record high temperatures were observed. While no fatalities occurred, several reports of heat-related illnesses were noted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessively hot temperatures of 108 to 113 degrees were observed below 4000 feet in southeast Arizona.  The high temperature record at the Tucson International Airport were tied on July 23 with 109 degrees and broken on the 24th and 25th with highs of 112 and 110 degrees, respectively. Tucson Fire, responded to at least six heat-related calls on July 24th.  On July 23rd, the Safford Airport reached 112 degrees and San Simon topped out at 108. A temperature of 111 degrees was attained at Sells on July 25th and at Ajo on both the 24th and 25th. Benson reached 110 on all three days.  Record highs were set at Bisbee-Douglas Airport on the 23rd and 24th with 105 and 104 degrees, respectively.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Afternoon heat indices peaked from 105 to 110 degrees across parts of southern Illinois, mainly southeast of a line from Carbondale to Mount Carmel. Southwest winds ahead of a cold front brought hot and humid air. Daytime high temperatures were in the lower to mid 90's, accompanied by high humidity.

The prolonged period of hazardous heat and humidity that began on June 29th persisted through the first several days of July. The most dangerous heat index values occurred on July 5th, when afternoon heat indices peaked around 110 degrees. Otherwise, the peak heat index each afternoon was near 105. Actual air temperatures were mostly in the lower to mid 90's. South winds ahead of a cold front brought heat and humidity on the 1st. The front stalled over the lower Ohio Valley on the 2nd, then returned northward. Another cold front approached on the 5th, preceded by hot and humid southwest winds.

A late-season heat wave impacted northwestern Connecticut during the first week of September. A persistent warm and moist airmass characterized by daytime highs in the 90s and dewpoints in the 70s resulted in heat index values reaching 95-105 degrees during the afternoon hours. This heat wave coincided with the first week of school for many, and the heat prompted some schools to cancel or dismiss classes early and postpone or cancel sports practices.

A large area of high pressure built into central California from the east on July 6 and brought a hot and dry airmass to the region which persisted through July 8. This produced a period of excessive heat across the Kern County deserts. The high weakened on July 9 resulting in a slight moderation of daytime temperatures in the desert areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 108 and 113 degrees at most locations between July 6 and July 8.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of high pressure built into central California from the east on July 6 and brought a hot and dry airmass to the region which persisted through July 8. This produced a period of excessive heat across the Kern County deserts. The high weakened on July 9 resulting in a slight moderation of daytime temperatures in the desert areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 108 and 113 degrees at most locations between July 6 and July 8.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of high pressure strengthened over the region on July 17 resulting a long stretch of days with 100 degree and warmer days across the San Joaquin Valley and the Kern County Deserts. The high strengthened over California on July 24. This resulted in several days of excessive heat over the Kern County Deserts where and Excessive Heat Warning was issued for a five day period, and a significant heat wave persisted across the San Joaquin Valley where emergency cooling centers were opened each afternoon in several municipalities between July 24 and July 28. Heat Advisories were posted for the San Joaquin Valley as well as for the lower elevations of the southern Sierra foothills and Kern County Mountains during this period. The high finally weakened on July 29 and 30 which allowed for temperatures to finally cool down closer to normal levels. The month turned out to be the warmest July on record for Fresno and the second warmest on record for Bakersfield.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 108 and 113 degrees at most locations between July 24 and July 28.

A late-season heat wave impacted eastern New York during the first week of September. A persistent warm and moist airmass characterized by daytime highs in the 90s and dewpoints in the 70s resulted in heat index values reaching 95-105 degrees during the afternoon hours. Daily record high temperatures were set or tied at Albany on the 5th and 6th, and a daily record high minimum temperature was set on the 3rd. This heat wave coincided with the first week of school for many, and the heat prompted some schools to dismiss classes early and postpone or cancel sports practices.

Heat indices remained persistently dangerous ahead of the cold front, while slightly lower values infiltrated northwest Kentucky.

Several days of oppressive heat and humidity were experienced across parts of west Kentucky. The extreme western end of the state was impacted the most. From Paducah south and west, heat indices peaked in the triple digits on five consecutive days. The highest heat indices were observed on the 14th, when values from 110 to 115 were recorded. Areas of northwest Kentucky including Owensboro and Henderson were impacted the least. At Owensboro and Henderson, heat indices peaked around 105 degrees on the 14th. Otherwise, heat index readings generally stayed below 100 in northwest Kentucky. High pressure over the Great Lakes region pushed a cold front down into the lower Ohio Valley. Heat indices remained persistently dangerous ahead of the cold front, while slightly lower values infiltrated northwest Kentucky.

The prolonged period of hazardous heat and humidity that began on June 29th persisted through the first several days of July. The most dangerous heat index values occurred on July 5th, when afternoon heat indices peaked around 110 degrees. Otherwise, the peak heat index each afternoon was near 105. Actual air temperatures were mostly in the lower to mid 90's. South winds ahead of a cold front brought heat and humidity on the 1st. The front stalled over the lower Ohio Valley on the 2nd, then returned northward. Another cold front approached on the 5th, preceded by hot and humid southwest winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure was anchored from South Texas across the Western Gulf of Mexico and across much of the Ark-La-Tex during May 15th. This resulted in much above normal temperatures areawide, with readings climbing into the lower 90s in the afternoon. ||A 6 month old girl died from heat stroke on May 15th after being left inside a hot car for about 6 hours, from around 11 am to 5 pm in the 6700 block of Woolworth Road in Shreveport. The high temperature in Shreveport on May 15th was 91 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably hot temperatures settled in across Northwest Louisiana during May 15th, with the high temperature in Shreveport climbing to 91 degrees. This temperature was just 3 degrees shy of tying the record high temperature of 94 degrees set back in 1881. ||A 6 month old girl died from heat stroke on May 15th after being left inside a hot car in  in the 6700 block of Woolworth Road in Shreveport for about 6 hours, from around 11 am to 5 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Reported from local CBS media: A 50-year-old Kansas woman was found dead in Palo Duro Canyon Friday afternoon. The Randall County Sheriff's Office said she had become separated from her family who were all hiking in the area. She was later found dead off the Lighthouse Trail. Authorities said the temperature was in the low 100s on Friday and she died of possible heat exhaustion.||According to local Palo Duro Canyon State Park Floor Mesonet observation site, the max temperatures on the 25th reached 107 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local Media reported A 50-year-old Kansas woman was found dead in Palo Duro Canyon Friday afternoon likely due to heat exhaustion.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dangerous combination of heat and humidity overspread the region beginning on June 28th and persisted through July 1st. There were 37 heat related illnesses reported in St. Louis County & the City of St. Louis during this event.

CZ_NAME: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong high pressure positioned over the Great Basin ushered in excessive temperatures into Southern California August 6-9. The desert areas and the Inland Empire experienced the hottest temperatures in this event. The inland areas experienced the brunt of the heat on August 6th-8th, with temperatures beginning to subside on August 9th. The coastal areas experienced their hottest temperatures on August 9th. The heat slowly began subsiding in all areas on August 10th, but remained quite hot throughout the week. Of significance, the Sea Surface Temperatures at La Jolla reached an all-time record high of 79.5F and several buoys reported 78-79F, peaking on August 9th. This is about 10 degrees above normal. The warm SST in July and August resulted in muggy conditions with dewpoints 70 to 72F reported for a few weeks at coastal observations including SAN. The minimum temperature did not drop below 70F at SAN for 36 consecutive days. Many days exceed 85F. August 2018 was the hottest on record for SAN (average temperature) and July and August combined was #2.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Inland Empire experienced temperatures in excess of 100 degrees on August 6th and 7th. Most areas in the Inland Empire experienced temperatures of 100-105 degrees, with the highest values observed in San Bernardino (108 degrees) and Lake Elsinore (111 degrees). The heat began to subside slightly on the 8th, with warm conditions continuing throughout the week.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Coachella Valley experienced the most extreme temperatures in Southern California during this heat event. Thermal hit 117 degrees and Palm Springs reach 115 degrees on August 6th. Similar temperatures were observed on August 7th as well. Heat began to subside on Thursday, August 9th, but it remained quite warm in the Coachella Valley through the entire week.

Temperatures dropped 3-4 degrees on August 7th, but still remained well above 100 degrees. Heat subsided slightly on August 8th and remained warm throughout the week.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Orange County Inland areas experienced hot temperatures during this heat event, with most areas experiencing temperatures over 95 degrees. The highest temperatures were observed on August 9th, with Anaheim reaching 100 degrees and Santa Ana reaching 97 degrees. August 6th-8th had temperatures slightly lower, but still remained above 95 degrees. Temperatures began to subside on Friday August 10th, but remained over 90 degrees through the weekend.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure to the south pumped hot and humid air northward across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 71 year old man was found dead in the driver's seat of a vehicle at 345 pm in Whitestone. Hyperthermia was the cause per an autopsy. Heat indices were in the lower to mid 90s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure over the south central United States resulted in a period of unseasonably hot weather over the area in late July. Temperatures on the 19th and 20th climbed to 100 to 105 degrees across much of eastern Oklahoma. This heat, combined with high humidity, resulted in afternoon heat index values from 105 to 112 degrees. At least 20 people were treated for heat-related illness in Tulsa on those dates.

This heat, combined with high humidity, resulted in afternoon heat index values from 105 to 112 degrees. At least 20 people were treated for heat-related illness in Tulsa on those dates.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late-season heat wave impacted eastern New York during the first week of September. A persistent warm and moist airmass characterized by daytime highs in the 90s and dewpoints in the 70s resulted in heat index values reaching 95-105 degrees during the afternoon hours. Daily record high temperatures were set or tied at Albany on the 5th and 6th, and a daily record high minimum temperature was set on the 3rd. This heat wave coincided with the first week of school for many, and the heat prompted some schools to dismiss classes early and postpone or cancel sports practices.

CZ_NAME: LOWER HELLS CANYON / SALMON RIVER REGION
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure brought a record breaking heat wave across lower elevations in north central Idaho August 9th and 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Pittsburg RAWS reached 116 on the 9th and 119 on the 10th.  RAWS have a well documented warm bias, so these temperatures are difficult to compare to other observations. Nevertheless, in this notoriously hot location, 119 appears to be the warmest in its period of record going back to 1993.  Furthermore, the Slate Creek RAWS reached 113 on the 9th and 114 on the 10th. Finally, Riggins reached 109 on the 10th, one degree shy of the record high of 110, with observations going back to 1896.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Temperatures in the upper 80s and lower 90s...along with dewpoints in the upper 60s...produced dangerous Heat Index values during the afternoons of the 6th and 7th across portions of the region. Heat Index values both afternoons generally ranged from the mid to upper 90s.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat Index values ranged from the mid to upper 90s during the afternoon hours.

A stalled ridge of strong high pressure over the region allowed high temperatures to climb well into the triple digits for many locations for multiple days.  Relative humidity values increased enough to make conditions unusually humid. These conditions combined to warrant the issuance of this area's first excessive heat warning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the afternoon hours of the 11th and 12th at the Glendive airport, high temperatures ranged from 102 to 106 degrees while dew points ranged from the mid 40s to mid 50s.  Even though this resulted in relative humidity values dropping down into the teens, the unusually hot temperatures and stagnant winds added stress to those with heat sensitivities.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled ridge of strong high pressure over the region allowed high temperatures to climb well into the triple digits for many locations for multiple days.  Relative humidity values increased enough to make conditions unusually humid. These conditions combined to warrant the issuance of this area's first excessive heat warning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the afternoon hours of the 10th and 11th at the Jordan airport, high temperatures ranged from 103 to 105 degrees while dew points ranged from the upper 30s to lower 40s. Even though this resulted in relative humidity values dropping down into the teens, the unusually hot temperatures and stagnant winds added stress to those with heat sensitivities.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled ridge of strong high pressure over the region allowed high temperatures to climb well into the triple digits for many locations for multiple days. Even though this resulted in relative humidity values dropping below ten percent, the unusually hot temperatures and stagnant winds added stress to those with heat sensitivities.

High pressure along the Eastern Seaboard brought very warm and very humid air into Southern New England.  Heat indices reached the lower 100s most places and mid 100s at one location.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Between Noon and 3 PM EST, the Automated Surface Observing System platform at Norwood Memorial Airport reported heat index values in the mid 100s.  The value was 107  at Noon EST, 108 at 1 PM EST, 104 at 2 PM EST, and 105 at 3 PM EST.

A bermuda high pumped hot and humid air northward across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The broadcast media reported an 11 year old girl died in Coram at 345 pm. The girl was found alone in a hot car. Heat indices reached 100 degrees at Islip MacArthur Airport during the afternoon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure brought a record breaking heat wave across lower elevations in north central Idaho August 9th and 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pierce set a record high of 101 on August 9th and an all-time record high of 105 on August 10th.  The two day mean maximum temperature of 103 at Pierce was the hottest on record with observations going back to 1963.  Elk River reached a high of 98 on the 9th and then set a record high of 102 on August 10th. Even though RAWS sites have displayed a warm bias, the Dent RAWS in close proximity to the Dworswak Reservoir reached 106 on the 9th and 105 on August 10th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure brought a record breaking heat wave across lower elevations in north central Idaho August 9th and 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cottonwood set record highs of 103 on the 10th and 99 on the 9th. The two day mean maximum temperature of 102 is the hottest two day stretch since observations began in 1976. Grangeville reached 104 on the 10th and 99 on the 9th. Kamiah just inside Spokane's County Warning Area recorded the second hottest two day mean maximum temperature stretch with 109.5. Kamiah set record highs of 109 on the 9th and 110 on the 10th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure brought a record breaking heat wave across lower elevations in northwest Montana August 9th and 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thompson Falls tied an all-time record high of 107 on the 10th and reached 106 on the 9th. The highest two day mean high temperature ever for Thompson Falls occurred on the 9th and the 10th with observations going back to 1956. Superior reached a record high of 105 on the 9th and 107 on the 10th, ranking as the third hottest two day maximum mean temperature stretch with observations going back to 1914.  Heron also set a record high of 102 on the 10th. Even though near-record to record high temperatures were observed on the 9th and 10th, overnight temperatures dropped in the mid to upper 50s at night.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure brought a record breaking heat wave across lower elevations in northwest Montana August 9th and 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Missoula reached a record high of 104 on the 10th. Hamilton and Stevensville recorded near record highs of 97 on the 10th. Even with record to near record highs on the 10th, overnight lows on the 9th and 10th dropped in the low to mid 50s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure brought a record breaking heat wave across lower elevations in northwest Montana August 9th and 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seeley Lake reached a record high of 98 on the 10th and tied a record high of 95 on the 9th. Potomac also set a record high of 100 on the 10th. Low temperatures on the 10th dropped into the low to mid 40s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure brought a record breaking heat wave across lower elevations in northwest Montana August 9th and 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Libby Dam recorded an all-time high temperature of 108 on the 10th with observations going back to 1986. In addition, a mean two day maximum temperature of 104.5 on the 9th and 10th was the hottest on record. Eureka set all-time record highs of 106 on the 9th and 10th.  The maximum two day mean of 106 is 1.5 degrees warmer than the next hottest two day stretch with observations going back to 1960. Troy also set a record high of 106 on the 10th. Even though record or near record highs were observed on the 9th and 10th, overnight lows still dropped into the mid 50s to low 60s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure brought a record breaking heat wave across lower elevations in northwest Montana August 9th and 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: West Glacier set an all-time record high of 100 on the August 10th. The two day mean high of 99.5 on the 9th and 10th was the hottest on record going back to 1948. Hungry Horse Dam also set a record high on the 10th of 102. Swan Lake reached 99 on the 9th and set an all-time record high of 106 on the 10th. This two day stretch tied the all-time hottest two day mean maximum temperature stretch with observations going back to 1963. Even with near record to record high temperatures lows were able to drop into the low 50s to upper 50s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure brought a record breaking heat wave across lower elevations in northwest Montana August 9th and 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Kalispell reached a record high of 100 on August 10th. Creston also record a record high of 98 on August 10th. The Hot Springs RAWS reached 107 and the Jette RAWS reached 103 on the 10th; however, RAWS sites tend to display a warm bias.  Low temperatures dropped into the low to mid 50s on the morning of the 10th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong high pressure system built westward from the Desert Southwest region on August 6 which provided for two days of hot temperatures across the Kern County Deserts on August 7 and 8. Highs generally ranged between 106 and 111 degrees on both days.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 106 and 111 degrees at most locations on August 8 and August 9.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Temperatures reached Excessive Heat Warning criteria in Las Vegas.  During and immediately after the excessive heat event, ten people died of heat related causes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive Heat Warning criteria were reached in Las Vegas for three days.  During this time and in the two days immediately following, ten people died of heat related causes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Eighteen people died of heat related causes in Las Vegas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eighteen people died in Las Vegas of heat related causes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Afternoon heat indices peaked between 100 and 105 degrees on three consecutive days from the 16th to the 18th. Actual air temperatures reached the mid 90's. When these temperatures were combined with dew points in the mid 70's, the heat index surpassed the century mark. A strong 500 mb high was centered over the lower Ohio and middle Mississippi Valleys during this heat wave.
