Temperatures reached Excessive Heat Warning levels on the 12th and 13th. One hiker suffering from dehydration and heat exposure was rescued from Death Valley National Park on the 15th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures reached Excessive Heat Warning levels on the 12th and 13th. One hiker suffering from dehydration and heat exposure was rescued on the 15th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Temperatures reached Excessive Heat Warning levels on the 12th and 13th. Five people died - four in Las Vegas and one in northeast Clark County - of heat related causes from the 13th through the 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures reached Excessive Heat Warning levels on the 12th and 13th. Four people died in Las Vegas of heat related causes on the 13th and 14th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid airmass invaded eastern New York beginning on June 30th. It would be the beginning of a heat wave that would last through the Independence Day holiday, and marked the first of several days of 90 degree heat. Combined with dewpoints in the mid-70s, heat indices reached around 100 degrees. The impending heat wave prompted the opening of numerous cooling centers throughout the region.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures reached Excessive Heat Warning levels on the 12th and 13th. One person died northeast of Glendale of heat related causes on the 13th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure to our south caused a west to southwest wind, resulting in humid conditions while subsidence from an upper-level ridge led to hot conditions. The combination of hot and humid conditions led to heat indices around 100 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices were estimated to be around 100 degrees based on observations nearby.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two to three days of hot and humid conditions produced heat index values in the 100's. Numerous cooling centers were opened by local communities throughout southern WI. Some public swimming pools hours were extended due to the heat. The heatwave continued into July 1st over far southeast WI.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values around 100 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Afternoon heat indices peaked between 100 and 105 degrees on three consecutive days from the 16th to the 18th. Actual air temperatures reached the lower to mid 90's. When these temperatures were combined with dew points in the mid 70's, the heat index surpassed the century mark. A strong 500 mb high was centered over the lower Ohio and middle Mississippi Valleys during this heat wave.

A large high pressure ridge strengthened off the California coast on June 22 and slowly built inland through June 24 providing the San Joaquin Valley with it's first prolonged period of triple digit heat in 2018. As a result of the widespread triple digit heat in the San Joaquin Valley during this period, several municipalities opened cooling centers during the afternoon hours. The ridge weakened and moved east of the area on June 25 allowing for cooler air to push into the San Joaquin Valley and end the hot spell.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 100 and 105 degrees at most locations between June 22 and June 24.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The heat index peaked from 100 to 109 degrees on the afternoons of the 29th and 30th. Actual high temperatures were in the lower 90's. These temperatures, combined with dew points in the upper 70's, produced hazardous conditions. A strong 500 mb high moved slowly east from the Mississippi Valley to the Appalachian Mountains during this heat wave.

During a three day period of very hot temperatures, a section of I-77 buckled in Washington County on the 19th. Nearby, the Beverly cooperative observer reported highs of 92 on the 18th, 91 on the 19th and 90 on the 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The northbound lanes of Interstate 77 near mile maker 10, or Highland Ridge Road) buckled due to heat. The road was closed for several hours as repairs were made.

Temperatures reached Excessive Heat Warning levels in Las Vegas. Four people died of heat related causes during and shortly after the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures reached Excessive Heat Warning levels in Las Vegas on the 4th. Four people died of heat related causes from the 4th through the 8th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Temperatures reached Excessive Heat Warning levels in Las Vegas on the 21st through 23rd. Two people died of heat related causes on the 21st.

A dangerous combination of heat and humidity overspread the region beginning on June 28th and persisted through July 1st. There were 37 heat related illnesses reported in St. Louis County & the City of St. Louis during this event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures were in the mid 90s with heat index values 106 or higher.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably hot and humid weather settled over Missouri on July 14th. Highs were between 95 and 100 with heat index values between 105 and 110. As a result, at least 8 people suffered heat-related illnesses and went to St. Louis metro area hospital emergency departments.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures were between 95 and 100 degrees on the 14th of July. This combined with dewpoints in the low to mid 70s created heat index values between 105 and 110. Four people suffered heat related illinesses.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure to our south caused a west to southwest wind, resulting in humid conditions while subsidence from an upper-level ridge led to hot conditions. The combination of hot and humid conditions led to heat indices around 100 to 105 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices were estimated to be around 100 degrees based on observations nearby. The Maryland Department of Health reported a fatality due to the heat.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot and humid weather occurred on June 30th in southwest lower Michigan.  High temperatures reached the lower to middle 90's which in conjunction with dew point values reaching the middle 70's resulted in heat indices that reached or exceeded 105 degrees at several locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The high temperature at Grand Rapids reached 94 degrees with a dew point of 76 degrees.  This resulted in a heat index reading of 107 degrees.

June ended with two days of excessive heat across western Wisconsin. Heat indices topped out between 105 and 115 on both June 29th and 30th, although the high heat indices were more widespread on the 29th. Air temperatures in the upper 80s to middle 90s with dew points in the middle 70s combined to create the excessive heat. The highest calculated heat index was 115 from mesonet stations in Mauston (Juneau County) and De Soto (Crawford County).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices of 105 to 115 were common across Buffalo County on June 29th and 30th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: June ended with two days of excessive heat across western Wisconsin. Heat indices topped out between 105 and 115 on both June 29th and 30th, although the high heat indices were more widespread on the 29th. Air temperatures in the upper 80s to middle 90s with dew points in the middle 70s combined to create the excessive heat. The highest calculated heat index was 115 from mesonet stations in Mauston (Juneau County) and De Soto (Crawford County).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices of 105 to 115 were common across Trempealeau County on June 29th and 30th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices of 105 to 110 were common across Jackson County on June 29th and 30th. The highest calculated heat index was 108 at a mesonet station near Black River Falls.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices of 105 to 115 were common across La Crosse County on June 29th and 30th. The highest calculated heat index was 114 by the automated weather observing equipment at the La Crosse airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper-level high pressure nearby and surface high pressure to our south and east caused hot and humid conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices were close to 100 degrees. The Maryland Department of Health reported three fatalities due to the heat during the week of July 10th through July 16th.

Very hot and humid weather occurred on June 30th in southwest lower Michigan.  High temperatures reached the lower to middle 90's which in conjunction with dew point values reaching the middle 70's resulted in heat indices that reached or exceeded 105 degrees at several locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The temperature at Mt. Pleasant municipal airport reached 93 degrees with a dew point of 75 degrees.  This resulted in a heat index reading of 105 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: June ended with two days of excessive heat across western Wisconsin. Heat indices topped out between 105 and 115 on both June 29th and 30th, although the high heat indices were more widespread on the 29th. Air temperatures in the upper 80s to middle 90s with dew points in the middle 70s combined to create the excessive heat. The highest calculated heat index was 115 from mesonet stations in Mauston (Juneau County) and De Soto (Crawford County).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices of 105 to 110 were common across Monroe County on June 29th and 30th. The highest calculated heat index was 106 by the automated weather observing equipment at the Sparta airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably hot and humid weather settled over Missouri during the Fourth of July holiday period. Highs were in the mid 90s with heat index values between 100 and 110. As a result, at least 100 people suffered heat-related illnesses at various outdoor events. Of these, approximately 35 people had to be taken to local hospitals for further treatment.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably hot and humid weather settled over Missouri during the Fourth of July holiday, July 4th and 5th. High temperatures were in the mid 90s both days with heat index values between 100 and 110. As a result, at least 50 people had to be treated for heat illnesses at Fair St. Louis, while approximately 20 people where taken to local hospitals for further treatment.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first significant heat wave of the 2018 summer season saw several days with temperatures well into the 90s over much of central Pennsylvania, and heat indices in excess of 100 degrees in the Lower Susquehanna Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values topped around 105 degrees in Adams County both Monday and Tuesday afternoon, July 2-3, 2018.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably hot and humid weather settled over Missouri during the Fourth of July holiday period. Highs were in the mid 90s with heat index values between 100 and 110. As a result, at least 100 people suffered heat-related illnesses at various outdoor events. Of these, approximately 35 people had to be taken to local hospitals for further treatment.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably hot and humid weather settled over Missouri during the Fourth of July holiday, July 4th and 5th. High temperatures were in the mid 90s both days with heat index values between 100 and 110. As a result, at least 20 people had to be treated for heat illnesses at various outdoor celebrations around St. Charles County, while approximately 2 people where taken to local hospitals for further treatment.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably hot and humid weather settled over Missouri during the Fourth of July holiday period. Highs were in the mid 90s with heat index values between 100 and 110. As a result, at least 100 people suffered heat-related illnesses at various outdoor events. Of these, approximately 35 people had to be taken to local hospitals for further treatment.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably hot and humid weather settled over Missouri during the Fourth of July holiday, July 4th and 5th. High temperatures were in the mid 90s both days with heat index values between 100 and 110. As a result, several dozen people had to be treated for heat illnesses at a number of outdoor celebrations, while approximately a dozen where taken to local hospitals for further treatment.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong broad upper level high pressure centered over Nevada and unusual weak offshore flow in July brought extreme hot temperatures and dry conditions to Southern California from July 6th through 8th. Inland Orange County, San Diego Valleys, Inland Empire and the deserts experienced the most extreme temperatures. July 6th was the hottest day during this event, with Thermal and Chino reaching 120 degrees, and San Bernardino and Riverside Airport reaching 118 degrees. July 7th and 8th remained quite hot -- only a few degrees cooler than July 6th. Heat began to subside significantly on July 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Even the desert was hot on July 6, 120F reported at Thermal and 119F at Palm Springs. These were shy of the 123-124F all-time highs. Palm Springs managed to reach 115F the following day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong broad upper level high pressure centered over Nevada and unusual weak offshore flow in July brought extreme hot temperatures and dry conditions to Southern California from July 6th through 8th. Inland Orange County, San Diego Valleys, Inland Empire and the deserts experienced the most extreme temperatures. July 6th was the hottest day during this event, with Thermal and Chino reaching 120 degrees, and San Bernardino and Riverside Airport reaching 118 degrees. July 7th and 8th remained quite hot -- only a few degrees cooler than July 6th. Heat began to subside significantly on July 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Santa Ana fire station climate site reached 114F on July 6, this was an all-time high. A scorching 115F was reported at Yorba Linda. On July 7, it still reached 109F at Yorba Linda.

CZ_NAME: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong broad upper level high pressure centered over Nevada and unusual weak offshore flow in July brought extreme hot temperatures and dry conditions to Southern California from July 6th through 8th. Inland Orange County, San Diego Valleys, Inland Empire and the deserts experienced the most extreme temperatures. July 6th was the hottest day during this event, with Thermal and Chino reaching 120 degrees, and San Bernardino and Riverside Airport reaching 118 degrees. July 7th and 8th remained quite hot -- only a few degrees cooler than July 6th. Heat began to subside significantly on July 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On July 6, temperature at Chino ASOS reached 120F. This is the highest recorded reading for this location and possibly for an ASOS not in the desert. Ontario ASOS reached 117F, the prior highest reading was 114F. Riverside Airport hit 118F and Lake Elsinore reach 119F. On Saturday July 7, the temperatures cooled to 114 at Chino, 113 at Riverside and 112 at Ontario.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High temperatures were in the mid 90s with heat index values around 105 in the St. Louis metro area for four straight days. Therefore the heat advisory was upgraded to an Excessive Heat Warning during the early morning hours of August 26th. Seven people were admitted to local hospitals for heat related illnesses.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures were in the mid 90s with heat index values around 105 in the St. Louis metro area. Four people were admitted to local hospitals for heat related illnesses in St. Louis County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong broad upper level high pressure centered over Nevada and unusual weak offshore flow in July brought extreme hot temperatures and dry conditions to Southern California from July 6th through 8th. Inland Orange County, San Diego Valleys, Inland Empire and the deserts experienced the most extreme temperatures. July 6th was the hottest day during this event, with Thermal and Chino reaching 120 degrees, and San Bernardino and Riverside Airport reaching 118 degrees. July 7th and 8th remained quite hot -- only a few degrees cooler than July 6th. Heat began to subside significantly on July 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Intense heat on July 6 (and offshore flow) resulted in breezy east winds and a high of 117F at Ramona ASOS. The previous record high was 111F. At Escondido the high was 112 and Santee 110, these were just shy of all-time highs. San Diego Public Health and 211 services share statistic which showed a sharp jump in heat related 911 and 211 information calls. 211 San Diego can provide vouchers for those in need of cool shelter during heat waves. The destructive West Fire also occurred in Alpine, San Diego County on July 6. Alpine had highs of 109 and 104 for July 6 and 7th with wind gusts to 30 mph.

A heatwave brought excessive heat warning conditions to much of southeast California.

Very strong high pressure aloft developed across the lower deserts of Arizona during a 3 day period ending on Wednesday July 25th; the exceedingly warm upper atmospheric conditions resulted in very hot temperatures over the lower deserts including the greater Phoenix metropolitan area. High temperatures each day across the hotter deserts reached or exceeded 115 degrees and low temperatures did not fall off, remaining in the mid 80s to the low 90s each day. Phoenix Sky Harbor reached 116 on the 24th and the 25th, tying and setting records for the dates. The extreme heat led to the death of a man found in the open desert near Apache Junction on July 24th. During the afternoon hours on July 25th, the excessive heat resulted in heat-related illnesses to multiple students at Gilbert High School including a teen who fell ill during afternoon football practice. An Excessive Heat Warning was in effect for all of the lower deserts of south central and southwest Arizona during the 3 day period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very strong high pressure aloft developed across the lower deserts of Arizona from July 23rd through July 25th which resulted in excessive heat across the lower deserts. The hotter lower deserts reached or exceeded 115 degrees each day during the 3 day period; Phoenix reached 116 degrees on both the 24th and 25th and both of these marks tied or broke daily records. Low temperatures remained in the upper 80s to low 90s each morning resulting in very dangerous conditions especially for those spending time outdoors during the heat of the day. The presence of excessive heat was confirmed via locally derived heat risk data. According to a report from local broadcast media, at 1738MST on July 25th a teen was taken to a hospital after suffering a heat-related illness during football practice at Gilbert High School, about 4 miles southwest of the town of Higley. Additionally, another student working outside during the afternoon was treated at the scene for heat-related illness. An Excessive Heat Warning was in effect for the area at the time of the reported illnesses.

Strong high pressure over the Desert Southwest allowed for temperatures to climb into record territory across the Phoenix area, resulting in deadly excessive heat conditions. Phoenix Sky Harbor airport recorded temperatures getting as high as 116 degrees during this period. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 40 heat-associated deaths occurred in the Phoenix area between July 22nd and July 31st. Without adequate precautions, highs in the triple digits, or even the 90s, are sufficient to cause serious health problems, especially to vulnerable or poorly prepared individuals such as the homeless or those without working air conditioners. Heat-associated fatality data as reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health is aggregated and unfortunately, specifics such as age, gender, and circumstances cannot be obtained.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Record breaking temperatures in the Phoenix area lead to a deadly excessive heat event during the latter half of July. Phoenix Sky Harbor recorded several days with highs reaching 115 degrees and 116 degrees during this time. According to Maricopa County Department of Public Health, there were 40 heat-associated deaths (32 direct and 8 indirect) that occurred during this event. Unfortunately, the Maricopa County Department of Health was unable to provide details such as age, gender or circumstances regarding the deaths.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure aloft along with plentiful sunshine allowed for temperatures to reach dangerous levels during the latter half of September. Temperatures at Phoenix Sky Harbor airport reached as high as 105 degrees during this time, which was enough to result in several heat-associated fatalities. According to Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 4 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time. Without adequate precautions, highs in the triple digits, or even the 90s, are sufficient to cause serious health problems. As reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, data are aggregated and unfortunately, specifics such as age, gender, location of fatalities, precise dates, and circumstances cannot be obtained.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dangerous heat continued into the latter half of September, leading to several additional fatalities for the month. Phoenix Sky Harbor airport recorded temperatures getting up to 105 degrees on September 28th, resulting in abnormally hot conditions. According to Maricopa County Department of Public Health, there were 4 heat-associated deaths (2 direct and 2 indirect) that occurred during this time. Unfortunately, the Maricopa County Department of Health was unable to provide details such as age, gender or circumstances regarding the deaths.

Very strong high pressure aloft developed across the lower deserts of Arizona during a 3 day period ending on Wednesday July 25th; the exceedingly warm upper atmospheric conditions resulted in very hot temperatures over the lower deserts including the greater Phoenix metropolitan area. High temperatures each day across the hotter deserts reached or exceeded 115 degrees and low temperatures did not fall off, remaining in the mid 80s to the low 90s each day. Phoenix Sky Harbor reached 116 on the 24th and the 25th, tying and setting records for the dates. The extreme heat led to the death of a man found in the open desert near Apache Junction on July 24th. During the afternoon hours on July 25th, the excessive heat resulted in heat-related illnesses to multiple students at Gilbert High School including a teen who fell ill during afternoon football practice. An Excessive Heat Warning was in effect for all of the lower deserts of south central and southwest Arizona during the 3 day period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very strong high pressure aloft developed over the southern deserts of Arizona beginning on July 23rd and this continued through July 25th, resulting in excessive heat across the lower deserts. The hotter lower deserts reached or exceeded 115 degrees each day which tied and broke records during the 3 day period. Phoenix reached 116 degrees on both the 24th and 25th; both marks tied or broke daily records. Low temperatures remained in the upper 80s to low 90s each morning resulting in very dangerous conditions especially for those spending time outdoors during the heat of the day. The presence of excessive heat was confirmed via locally derived heat risk data. Unfortunately, the excessive heat led to a fatality; a man was found dead in the open desert at 1605MST on July 24th. He was located about 3 miles southeast of Apache Junction, near the intersection of Baseline and Goldfield Roads. Paramedics and the fire department believed that the man's death was due to the excessive heat. An Excessive Heat Warning was in effect at the time of the fatality.

High pressure ridging brought hot temperatures across the area, 5 to 10 degrees above normal. Some locations had high temperatures reaching 105-110, with temperatures remaining in the mid to upper 70s overnight. Heat Warnings and Advisories were issued. Heat Risk Criteria reached Moderate levels across the forecast area, with some areas in the northern Sacramento Valley and adjacent foothills reaching High to Very High levels.||Isolated nocturnal thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to the mountains, causing a rock slide.||A period of less extreme heat came earlier in the month. A 2 year old boy died in a hot car on July 7 in south Sacramento. The high temperature in downtown Sacramento reached 100 that day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The NWS Experimental Heat Risk reached Moderate to High readings for several days prompting a Heat Advisory for northern Shasta County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The NWS Experimental Heat Risk reached Moderate to High readings for several days prompting a Heat Advisory for the Central Sacramento Valley. The hottest day was the 18th, when the temperature reached 104 at Marysville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure ridging brought hot temperatures across the area, 8 to 15 degrees above normal. Heat Warnings and Advisories were issued. Heat Risk Criteria reached Moderate levels across the forecast area, with some areas in the northern Sacramento Valley and adjacent foothills reaching High to Very High levels.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures during the latter half of August 2018 led to additional fatalities for the month. High pressure aloft along with plentiful sunshine allowed for temperatures to reach dangerous levels. Phoenix Sky Harbor airport recorded temperatures getting up to 108 degrees on a couple of instances during this time. The excessive heat combined with increased humidity was sufficient to result in a number of fatalities across the greater Phoenix area. According to Maricopa County Department of Public Health, there were 18 heat-associated deaths that occurred during this time. Without adequate precautions, highs in the triple digits, or even the 90s, are sufficient to cause serious health problems. As reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, the data are aggregated and unfortunately, specifics such as age, gender, location of fatality, and circumstances cannot be obtained.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures during the latter half of August were enough to result in additional fatalities for the month. Phoenix Sky Harbor airport recorded temperatures reaching 108 degrees on August 19th and 20th, which is above seasonal normal values. According to Maricopa County Department of Public Health, there were 18 heat-associated (5 direct and 13 indirect) during this time. Unfortunately, the Maricopa County Department of Health was unable to provide details such as age, gender or circumstances regarding the deaths.

CZ_NAME: UPPER GILA RIVER AND ARAVAIPA VALLEYS
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures occurred in the valleys of southeast Arizona from July 23rd through July 25th.  A number of record high temperatures were observed and several reports of heat-related illnesses were noted.  Two heat-related deaths occurred--one just east of Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument and another on the Tohono O'odham Nation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessively hot temperatures of 105 to 113 degrees were observed below 5000 feet in southeast Arizona.  High temperature records at the Tucson International Airport were tied on July 23 with 109 degrees and broken on the 24th and 25th with highs of 112 and 110 degrees, respectively. On July 23rd, the Safford Airport reached 112 degrees and San Simon topped out at 108. A temperature of 111 degrees was attained at Sells on July 25th and at Ajo and at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument on both the 24th and 25th. Benson reached 110 on all three days.  Record highs were set at Bisbee-Douglas Airport on the 23rd and 24th with 105 and 104 degrees, respectively. Tucson Fire responded to at least six heat-related calls on July 24th. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two adult males. One occurred just east of Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument on the 24th. The second occurred on the Tohono O'odham Nation near the International Border.  The exact time of death was not determinable, but very likely occurred on July 25th.

Hot temperatures in the mid to upper 90s were experienced in parts of southeast Arizona on May 16th through the 18th.  One heat-related fatality occurred east of Sierra Vista.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Well above normal temperatures occurred in the San Pedro River Valley of Cochise County May 16th through May 18th.  The hottest day was May 17th when a high temperature of 96 degrees was recorded at Tombstone and 97 degrees at Saint David.  The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one adult male near the San Pedro River north of State Route 90.  The exact date that the fatality occurred is not certain, but likely occurred within this three-day time period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures and high humidity contributed to the hot car death of an infant in Davidson County on May 23.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 1 year old girl named Katera Barker died of heat stroke after being left in a pickup truck on Virginia Avenue in East Nashville during the day on Wednesday, May 23. At the nearby Nashville International Airport ASOS, the high temperature reached 89 with a dewpoint of 65, giving a peak heat index of 91.

Hot temperatures were experienced in parts of southeast Arizona on May 5th and 6th with a temperature of 102 degrees recorded at Sells. One heat-related fatality occurred east of Sells.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Well above normal temperatures occurred on the Tohono O'odham Nation on May 5th and 6th.  Sells recorded a high temperature of 102 degrees on both days. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one adult female east of Sells.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures occurred in Tucson and the deserts west of Tucson on July 5th through the 7th.  Several record high temperatures occurred. Two heat-related deaths occurred--one at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument and another on the Tohono O'odham Nation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures from July 5th through July 7th were between 105 and 113 from Tucson westward across Pima County and in southwest Pinal County, which were significantly above normal. Respective high temperatures include: Tucson International Airport 111 (record), 105 and 107 degrees; Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument 113, 113 (record) and 109 degrees; Sells 113 (record), 107 and 106 degrees; and Picacho 111, 109, 110 degrees.  Green Valley also set a record high temperature of 108 degrees on July 7th. A hiker suffering from heat exhaustion at Sabino Canyon was rescued and taken to a hospital for treatment on July 8th. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two adult males, one on the grounds of Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument on the 5th and another on the Tohono O'odham Nation south of Sells near the International Border on the 7th.

Very hot temperatures occurred in the valleys of southeast Arizona from July 23rd through July 25th.  A number of record high temperatures were observed and several reports of heat-related illnesses were noted.  Two heat-related deaths occurred--one just east of Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument and another on the Tohono O'odham Nation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessively hot temperatures of 105 to 113 degrees were observed below 5000 feet in southeast Arizona.  High temperature records at the Tucson International Airport were tied on July 23 with 109 degrees and broken on the 24th and 25th with highs of 112 and 110 degrees, respectively. On July 23rd, the Safford Airport reached 112 degrees and San Simon topped out at 108. A temperature of 111 degrees was attained at Sells on July 25th and at Ajo and at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument on both the 24th and 25th. Benson reached 110 on all three days.  Record highs were set at Bisbee-Douglas Airport on the 23rd and 24th with 105 and 104 degrees, respectively. Tucson Fire responded to at least six heat-related calls on July 24th. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two adult males. One occurred just east of Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument on the 24th. The second occurred on the Tohono O'odham Nation near the International Border.  The exact time of death was not determinable, but very likely occurred on July 25th.

The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two adult males. One occurred just east of Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument on the 24th. The second occurred on the Tohono O'odham Nation near the International Border.  The exact time of death was not determinable, but very likely occurred on July 25th.

Very hot temperatures occurred in the valleys of southeast Arizona from July 23rd through July 25th.  A number of record high temperatures were observed and several reports of heat-related illnesses were noted.  Two heat-related deaths occurred--one just east of Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument and another on the Tohono O'odham Nation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessively hot temperatures of 105 to 113 degrees were observed below 5000 feet in southeast Arizona.  High temperature records at the Tucson International Airport were tied on July 23 with 109 degrees and broken on the 24th and 25th with highs of 112 and 110 degrees, respectively. On July 23rd, the Safford Airport reached 112 degrees and San Simon topped out at 108. A temperature of 111 degrees was attained at Sells on July 25th and at Ajo and at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument on both the 24th and 25th. Benson reached 110 on all three days.  Record highs were set at Bisbee-Douglas Airport on the 23rd and 24th with 105 and 104 degrees, respectively. Tucson Fire responded to at least six heat-related calls on July 24th. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two adult males. One occurred just east of Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument on the 24th. The second occurred on the Tohono O'odham Nation near the International Border.  The exact time of death was not determinable, but very likely occurred on July 25th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures during the latter half of August 2018 led to additional fatalities for the month. High pressure aloft along with plentiful sunshine allowed for temperatures to reach dangerous levels. Phoenix Sky Harbor airport recorded temperatures getting up to 108 degrees on a couple of instances during this time. The excessive heat combined with increased humidity was sufficient to result in a number of fatalities across the greater Phoenix area. According to Maricopa County Department of Public Health, there were 18 heat-associated deaths that occurred during this time. Without adequate precautions, highs in the triple digits, or even the 90s, are sufficient to cause serious health problems. As reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, the data are aggregated and unfortunately, specifics such as age, gender, location of fatality, and circumstances cannot be obtained.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures during the latter half of August were enough to result in additional fatalities for the month. Phoenix Sky Harbor airport recorded temperatures reaching 108 degrees on August 19th and 20th, which is above seasonal normal values. According to Maricopa County Department of Public Health, there were 18 heat-associated (5 direct and 13 indirect) during this time. Unfortunately, the Maricopa County Department of Health was unable to provide details such as age, gender or circumstances regarding the deaths.

CZ_NAME: UPPER SANTA CRUZ RIVER AND ALTAR VALLEYS
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures were experienced in parts of southeast Arizona on June 22nd and 23rd. Two heat-related fatalities occurred--one on the Tohono O'odham Nation and another in western Santa Cruz County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Well above normal temperatures occurred in southeast Arizona on June 22nd and 23rd. Temperatures as hot as 108 degrees occurred at Ajo, Picacho and Safford Airport with 107 at Sasabe (record) and Sells and 106 at Tucson International Airport and Green Valley. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two adults, one west of Ruby in Santa Cruz County on the 22nd and another on the Tohono O'odham Nation in southwest Pinal County on the 23rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures were experienced in parts of southeast Arizona on June 26th.  One heat-related fatality occurred in Cochise County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Well above normal temperatures occurred in Cochise County on June 26th. A temperature of 107 degrees occurred at Cascabel with 100 at Benson and Willcox. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one adult male west of Dragoon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were experienced in parts of southeast Arizona on June 13th with several new record highs established. Two heat-related fatalities occurred--one in western Pima County and another in northwest Santa Cruz County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Well above normal temperatures occurred in southeast Arizona on June 13th.  Several new record high temperatures were established including 110 degrees at Picacho, 109 at Safford Airport, 107 at Duncan and 105 at Sasabe. Other high temperatures included 107 at Sells. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two adult males, one west of Ajo, and another in northwest Santa Cruz County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heat in the latter half of the month proved to be fatal across the Phoenix metropolitan area. Temperatures rose into the upper 90s to around 100 as high pressure aloft built into the Southwest. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, there were 2 heat-caused fatalities and 3 heat-related fatalities in Maricopa County May 20-25. As reported to Phoenix, the data are aggregrated and represent monthly values for several combined communities. Unfortunately, specifics such as age, gender, location of fatality, and circumstances cannot be obtained.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures rose into the upper 90s to around 100, resulting in unusually hot conditions. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, there was 1 indirect heat fatality.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure over the Desert Southwest allowed for temperatures to climb into record territory across the Phoenix area, resulting in deadly excessive heat conditions. Phoenix Sky Harbor airport recorded temperatures getting as high as 116 degrees during this period. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 40 heat-associated deaths occurred in the Phoenix area between July 22nd and July 31st. Without adequate precautions, highs in the triple digits, or even the 90s, are sufficient to cause serious health problems, especially to vulnerable or poorly prepared individuals such as the homeless or those without working air conditioners. Heat-associated fatality data as reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health is aggregated and unfortunately, specifics such as age, gender, and circumstances cannot be obtained.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Record breaking temperatures in the Phoenix area lead to a deadly excessive heat event during the latter half of July. Phoenix Sky Harbor recorded several days with highs reaching 115 degrees and 116 degrees during this time. According to Maricopa County Department of Public Health, there were 40 heat-associated deaths (32 direct and 8 indirect) that occurred during this event. Unfortunately, the Maricopa County Department of Health was unable to provide details such as age, gender or circumstances regarding the deaths.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dangerous heat wave, one of which that likely hasn't impacted the North Country in decades occurred between June 30th and July 5th. High temperatures exceeded 90 degrees for at least 5 of the six days in many locations were above 85 degrees for 7 days.|Heat indices, the combination of temperature and humidity, were recorded in the 100 to 110 range considered excessive and very dangerous. A substantial increase in hospitalizations occurred due to the excessive heat and duration.||A weak disturbance moving across a very hot and humid air mass on July 2nd initiated isolated thunderstorms, one of which that produced very localized wind damage. Similarly, one isolated thunderstorm produced a brief downburst at NY Mesonet site on July 5th with no reported damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures in the upper 80s to upper 90s with dewpoints in the 60s and 70s created dangerous heat indices in the 95 to 110 degree range between June 30th and July 5th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dangerous heat wave, one of which that likely hasn't impacted the North Country in decades occurred between June 30th and July 5th. High temperatures exceeded 90 degrees for at least 5 of the six days in many locations were above 85 degrees for 7 days. |Heat indices, the combination of temperature and humidity, were recorded in the 100 to 110 range considered excessive and very dangerous. A substantial increase in hospitalizations occurred due to the excessive heat and duration and at least 4 deaths were attributed to the heat.||Burlington VT witnessed the warmest 5 and 6 Day Consecutive stretch since records have been kept in 1892. Also, the ALL-TIME warmest minimum temperature was recorded on July 2nd of 80 degrees, breaking the old record of 78 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures in the upper 80s to upper 90s with dewpoints in the 60s and 70s created dangerous heat indices in the 95 to 110 degree range between June 30th and July 5th.||Three fatalities were reported in official state health department records.  A 79-year-old female in Essex Junction, 57-year-old female in Milton, and 71-year-old male all died in their places of residence from Hyperthermia.||Increased hospitalization visits also occurred due to the dangerous heat.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dangerous heat wave, one of which that likely hasn't impacted the North Country in decades occurred between June 30th and July 5th. High temperatures exceeded 90 degrees for at least 5 of the six days in many locations were above 85 degrees for 7 days. |Heat indices, the combination of temperature and humidity, were recorded in the 100 to 110 range considered excessive and very dangerous. A substantial increase in hospitalizations occurred due to the excessive heat and duration and at least 4 deaths were attributed to the heat.||Burlington VT witnessed the warmest 5 and 6 Day Consecutive stretch since records have been kept in 1892. Also, the ALL-TIME warmest minimum temperature was recorded on July 2nd of 80 degrees, breaking the old record of 78 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures in the upper 80s to upper 90s with dewpoints in the 60s and 70s created dangerous heat indices in the 95 to 110 degree range between June 30th and July 5th.||Increased hospitalization visits occurred due to the dangerous heat.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dangerous heat wave, one of which that likely hasn't impacted the North Country in decades occurred between June 30th and July 5th. High temperatures exceeded 90 degrees for at least 5 of the six days in many locations were above 85 degrees for 7 days. |Heat indices, the combination of temperature and humidity, were recorded in the 100 to 110 range considered excessive and very dangerous. A substantial increase in hospitalizations occurred due to the excessive heat and duration and at least 4 deaths were attributed to the heat.||Burlington VT witnessed the warmest 5 and 6 Day Consecutive stretch since records have been kept in 1892. Also, the ALL-TIME warmest minimum temperature was recorded on July 2nd of 80 degrees, breaking the old record of 78 degrees.
